ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Markov chains, martingales, Brownian motion

I think this course was a great introduction to the field of random processes. Professor Chang offered intuitive explanations for complex topics and tried to make the material as accessible as possible to students.
Using this course, I began to think about my life from the perspectives of stochastic processes.
I learned about Markov chains, martingales, branching procceses, and a little about hidden markov models.
Topics in stochastic processes like brownian motion, markov chains, branching processes

Understanding of probability theory beyond the iid assumption. I.e. understanding of basic types of stochastic process and principles behind them. Stochastic processes in both discrete and continuous time and state spaces
I learned about Markov chains, martingales, and Brownian motion.
Markov chains, martingales, Brownian motion

Knowledge of basic stochastic processes, Markov Chains, Monte Carlo simulations, Metropolis Hastings, Martingales, Brownian Motion, Stochastic Calculus

A good grasp of stochastic processes in general, abstraction of stochastic processes into other fields, practice with expectation and probability
Overview of Markov Chain, Martingale, and Brownian motion theories and some real-world applications.
A lot of fundamental knowledge on stochastic processes. Can be very useful in modeling all kinds of things
Stochastic processes, markov chains, brownian motion, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: At times it felt a little disorganized, but not in a 'classes and the material felt scattered and incoherent. For example, the date for the midterm was not known until the work before(if I recall correctly), but I somehow ended up not being bothered by that. The class notes were amazing and I really enjoyed Professor Chang's teaching style. He really tried to make complex and abstract topics accessible to students. The psets were challenging but rewarding.
Professor is great, as are the course notes. It was a shame it was virtual - it's hard to pay good attention on Zoom. I think the Professor could be slightly more responsive to emails.

Thought it might be better to have this course involve a more proof-based approach (measure theory based), although that is probably not what most of the students are looking for. Maybe it could be good to have two versions of the this class, with one more focused on rigorous proofs.

Overall I thought the course was very interesting and I learned a lot from it. I thought that the combination of the live lectures and the full lecture notes were very helpful to reference. I learned a lot from doing the psets. I thought Professor Chang did a great job with the course and I thought he explained the content well in class and did a good job answering student questions. 

I think my biggest grievances with the course were how some of the ULA office hours were run. I recognize it was difficult for them this year since most of them had taken the class with a different professor, so it mostly wasn't really their fault and would probably improve in future years. However, in the first couple office hours I went to it seemed like the ULA didn't understand the homework question or my questions about it, and they even gave me a couple suggestions that ultimately led me astray and turned out incorrect. Towards the end of the semester I started going to ULA office hours again, this time to Eduardo's office hours, and those were frustrating in a different way because he would essentially just write out most of the answers to the pset questions for everyone. It seemed like he was often generally writing directly from the answer key, albeit usually not writing the entire solution, but generally not particularly challenging students to think for themselves. There were also some comments he made that felt a bit like mild put downs like "I hope everyone took the 8th grade," "everyone should understand MCMC by now" (before realizing the confusing parts about it that he late struggled to explain), and "you should know what this converges to, don't plot it" (before then later realizing that he didn't know what it converges to and having to plot it himself). These weren't awful instances or anything but I guess it just didn't feel like the most welcoming learning environment, more just like someone was sharing answers and less to explain concepts and meet students where they were at. I recognize it is a difficult balance to strike between giving sufficient versus too much help, but it was frustrating to on the one hand early in the semester not be able to have my questions answered or have them answered in a misleading way and then at the end of the semester feel like everyone was just being given pset answers without helping us to understand concepts or challenging us to think for ourselves so much. This is just one perspective though and I think other people enjoyed the later office hours, so my perspective of course should be taken with a grain of salt.

The only strength of this class was the textbook. The weaknesses of the class include the unclear and boring lectures based on a better textbook, the unreasonably long and hard assignments and exams, and ridiculousness of the optional final project. Never have I seen a professor decide to make people inevitably cry when taking a final exam, given its absurd difficulty.

The course material itself was interesting, and highly relevant to a lot of fields. However, the lectures and overall course structure were highly disorganized. There was little clarity as to the overall course direction and several of the smaller topics/applications felt unmotivated. In particular, the second half of the course was really scattered, and we did not delve into any of the concepts in detail. Students were given little direction as to what would be on the final.

Not too many strengths. The topics have potential to be interesting
The course itself was taught very poorly, and the problem sets  though interesting and somewhat inspiring  seemed to deviate from the material a bit too much. The exams were amazingly difficult and made us feel somewhat defeated by the end of the semester. Perhaps if you are a genius or find these topics very inspiring, you could do well, but for most of us, I dont think that was the case.

Strength: I love Professor Chang's written notebook and his genuine care for students. 

Weakness: I don't think there was an obvious one.

Class was rather disorganized, some material went by way too fast, while others were way too slow. Not exactly sure who the intended audience was - math majors with lots of proficiency with proofs, or people who are more inclined to computation.
I think the second half of the course was rushed compared to the first half. It wouldve been nice to go at a slower pace in the second half of the course.

Strength: Joe Chang is a pretty good lecturer and most lectures were pretty intuitive and engaging, weekly psets weren't too bad with office hours, overall pretty good class

Weakness: when we got to hard/unintuitive topics in class (e.g. differential equations) things weren't explained very well, exams were pretty difficult.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We used Ed to post questions and the staff really tried to engage and answer in as much detail as possible. The recordings of classes were posted online which was very useful. I think this class could have benefited from a few more ULAs. Overall I think they did great given the available resources.
I appreciated how there were a range of different office hour times available. Recorded lectures were nice in case you had to miss one.
The Zoom lectures were not helpful since he regurgitated content from his textbook, which explained everything much better.
Recorded lectures helped, as it was easy to miss certain concepts/explanations in live lecture.
I think it was pretty solid given the situation.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yeah it's some interesting and useful content. Felt we went a bit slowly on Markov chains. The graders are out to get you and will actively look for any reason to take points off.
Absolutely! Joe Chang is an amazing professor and the topic is super interesting! Honestly just take anything Joe teaches.
I will always recommend every class with Joe Chang! He's such a knolwedgable, kind, and reasonable professor.
Yes. It is necessary for public health students who want to do data scientist.
Absolutely. The material is very interesting and also very applicable (which is a rarity for math classes!)

Probably not. I took this class because I was interested in the material, and it was very interesting, but I don't think the course was set up very well for student learning. It's a large lecture but there weren't many teaching staff, and communication with them was kind of slow. The lectures themselves were hard to follow some times, and the weekly psets took a while as well. The exams, especially the final, were pretty difficult.
I took this course just because I needed an upper level math course. Would not recommend doing this if there are other options available. Only take it if youre passionate about statistics.
looks easy but really isn't
Yes if you have taken probability theory or equivalent before, enjoyed that course, want to learn more about probability and stochastic processes, and like both proof based math and applied stats.
No - just read his textbook and learn a lot more that way.
No, just read some notes or a textbook on Stochastic Processes.

A resounding NO! Please do not take this class. I think previous iterations were bad, and this one was bad too. The lectures were disorganized and it was hard to see the big picture of everything until the course was finally finished. The problem sets were difficult, and the topics had little motivation, so the class seemed really boring in general. I would recommend socially distancing yourself from this class and take something more interesting and rigorous, such as advanced probability or real analysis. The class is even worse when you have students in the class who ask irrelevant questions, and with a professor whos really nice and has the willingness to respond to these questions in detail, the class basically became a daily session of pulling teeth.
Yes. Stochastic is very important in multiple areas in natural and social sciences. If you can, take it with Professor Chang.
Eh, the material is necessary, but the experience wasn't really pleasant.
Id definitely recommend if you want your future work to revolve around statistics / any kind of statistical modeling
Yeah, I think this is a pretty great class and stochastic processes is a really interesting field. Joe Chang is also really funny and he has a cute dog named Cauchy!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The lectures were held live, but the recordings were posted on Canvas.
Live + Recorded
None

Lectures were also recorded, and there were office hours. Also most of learning was through psets along with reading notes and studying for exams, and through the final project for people who decided to do it.
There was also a live virtual lecture, but watching it in normal speed was excruciating, so I opted to watch 2x as a recording. 80+ of my peers would agree.
In class Qs
